entries.title: Hillcrest beats Lemont, says it is 'state or bust' as the IHSA releases the state tournament brackets
entries.summary: <p>Hillcrest’s season took a major turn when 6-7 senior Max Carmicle suffered a season-ending injury in early December. The Purdue-bound defensive lineman was also the focal point of the basketball team.</p><p>“We had high expectations early in the year and when Max went down, it threw us completely off,” coach Don Houston said. “We had to learn how to play without him. He was a potential all-stater.”</p><p>Carmicle’s injury meant major minutes for 6-7 junior Terrence Richardson.</p><p>“Terrence was a 5-9, B-team player in his freshman year,” Houston said. “He just stretched out and then he had to learn how to play with his length.”</p><p>Richardson didn’t have the physical mindset for post play early in the season.</p><p>“Terrence started out the season soft,” Hillcrest guard Jamir Ratliff said. “But he got a tougher mindset and got better from there.”</p><p>Richardson scored seven points and grabbed 13 rebounds in the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/super-25-basketball-rankings/2026/02/08/high-school-basketball-rankings-chicago-illinois-sun-times-michael-obrien" >No. 25 Hawks’ </a>60-49 victory at Lemont on <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-basketball/scores/2026/02/13/chicago-illinois-high-school-basketball-scores" >Friday</a>.</p><p>“We put a lot of work into toughening him up,” Houston said. “He’s been doing a great job.”</p><p>The softness is gone now, and Richardson plays like a promising college prospect.</p><p>“I’ve been up and down and up and down this season,” Richardson said. “It’s been a lot.”</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-5e0000" class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Hillcrest’s Terrence Richardson (12) gets fouled but makes this shot in the first half of the Hawks’ 60-49 victory over Lemont.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Allen Cunningham/For the Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>The Hawks (19-7, 12-0 South Suburban Blue) have a talented backcourt to handle the scoring load. Ratliff scored 17 points against Lemont to crack the 1,000-point mark in his career.</p><p>“Hitting 1,000 feels good, but it was never really the goal,” Ratliff said. “It just happened naturally.”</p><p>Sophomore Ja’Sean Greene added 14 points for Hillcrest with some dynamic moves to the basket and senior point guard Jamari Thomas handled Lemont’s pressure with grace.</p><p>“[Greene] has been playing like that all season,” Houston said. “He gives us solid minutes and he’s probably our best defender. He’s only going to continue to get better. He will step up huge for us next year.”</p><p>Lemont (15-12, 9-3) jumped out to a 19-9 lead and still led 29-28 at halftime but only scored one field goal in the first 12 minutes of the second half as Hillcrest took control.</p><p>Junior Zane Schneider led Lemont with 22 points, and 6-5 senior Ryan Crane added 11 points and seven rebounds.</p><p>Hillcrest joined the Super 25 on Sunday after knocking off Kenwood by 22 points last week. The Hawks’ only losses in 2026 are to York and Curie, and they played the Condors tough, losing by just two points.</p><p>“We are playing to the competition level,” Houston said. “But overall, we are starting to find ourselves now. It is state or bust.”</p><p>Hillcrest hosts a Class 3A sectional. The Hawks are the No. 2 seed behind Leo, and the path to Champaign looks very promising. The Illinois High School Association released the full state tournament playoff brackets on Friday evening. Crete-Monee and Thornton are the other contenders.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-b40000" name="html-embed-module-b40000"></a><iframe title="No Shot Clock, Ep. 201: Conference quick takes" allowtransparency="true" height="150" width="100%" style="border: none; min-width: min(100%, 430px);height:150px;" scrolling="no" data-name="pb-iframe-player" src="https://www.podbean.com/player-v2/?i=5patj-1a40c88-pb&from=pb6admin&share=1&download=1&rtl=0&fonts=Arial&skin=1&font-color=auto&logo_link=episode_page&btn-skin=c73a3a" loading="lazy"></iframe> </div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Michael O'Brien

entries.title: What Pete Crow-Armstrong can learn from Cubs and Team USA teammate Alex Bregman
entries.summary: <p>MESA, Ariz. — New <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs" target="_blank" >Cubs</a> third baseman Alex Bregman knows his swing is at its best when he is stingy with his pitch selection and makes contact out in front. Those keys unlocked what he called the best 1½-month offensive stretch of his life last season before a strained quad in late May broke his rhythm.</p><p>The same things are focuses for Cubs center fielder Pete Crow-Armstrong, especially disciplined swing decisions. That has dominated most of their hitting conversations so far.</p><p>‘‘I think the sky’s the limit for him,’’ Bregman said of Crow-Armstrong. ‘‘I feel like he can do anything on a baseball field: running the bases, defensively, offensively. And I feel like the more he refines his game, he’s just going to continue to get better and better.’’</p><p>Bregman joined the Cubs with an already-glowing reputation for his <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/cubs/2026/01/15/cubs-tout-alex-bregmans-leadership-as-they-enter-long-term-commitment" target="_blank" >leadership skills</a>. The examples keep stacking up.</p><p>Bregman was in the coaches’ room earlier this week, president of baseball operations Jed Hoyer said, asking about what his teammates were working on and how he could reinforce those cues. During the offseason, young infielder Matt Shaw joined Bregman at his facility in Arizona to hit.</p><p>‘‘It’s rare to have a player that’s invested in helping make young guys better,’’ Hoyer said. ‘‘And you’ll see it in various ways, but it’s a wonderful quality that he has. It’s something people with the Astros talk about and people with the Red Sox talk about, and it’s something he’s earned.’’</p><p>Bregman is expected to make an impact on the Cubs all season. But because of the World Baseball Classic schedule this spring, there’s one young position player he’ll be around more than any other.</p><p>‘‘I’m really excited to spend some serious time with him,’’ Crow-Armstrong said of Bregman, who will join him on Team USA. ‘‘The guy is super-enthusiastic about the intricacies of the game. And I’ve loved hearing him share his experiences in the past. And I think he’s going to make me and the whole squad just a whole lot better.’’</p><p>Bregman and Crow-Armstrong were early arrivals in camp. And though Bregman left the complex Thursday with an illness, he was back Friday.</p><p>The two have about two more weeks left with the Cubs before joining Team USA for WBC play. It will be Crow-Armstrong’s first WBC and Bregman’s second.</p><p>In 2017, Bregman was the youngest player on Team USA’s squad, turning 23 about a week after the team beat Puerto Rico in the final. The next time around, in 2023, Bregman couldn’t participate after breaking a finger in the World Series several months before.</p><p>‘‘I didn’t get to play that much [in 2017], but I got to experience it,’’ Bregman said. ‘‘And I’ve been looking forward to this since then.’’</p><p>Bregman can pass lessons from that early experience to the 23-year-old Crow-Armstrong, but the two will have more time for general baseball conversations, too. Pitch selection is sure to continue to be a topic between them.</p><p>Bregman’s elite chase rate put him in the 95th percentile in that category last season. Crow-Armstrong, meanwhile, is well aware that he’s a free swinger and that improving his command of the strike zone is an avenue to take his offensive game to a new level.</p><p>‘‘It’s not the first time Pete’s talked about pitch selection,’’ Cubs manager Craig Counsell said of Crow-Armstrong’s conversations with Bregman. ‘‘But, kind of like pitch grips, how it clicks for you and how you see it and how it resonates and how you process it, it’s different for everybody.’’</p><p>The more conversations Crow-Armstrong has with coaches or teammates who excel in that area, the more chances he will create to have that ‘‘aha’’ moment.</p><p>‘‘The way Alex approaches it, he’s been successful, and it’s been successful for other players, as well,’’ Counsell said. ‘‘So of course we’re all going to listen to that.’’</p><bsp-listcarousel class="PageListE" data-module data-column-count=3 data-hide-authors="true" data-hide-categories="true" data-hide-dates="true" data-hide-descriptions="true" entries.title: Horoscope for Saturday, February 14, 2026
entries.summary: <h2>Moon Alert</h2> <p>Avoid shopping (except food and gas) and important decisions after 7:15 p.m. After that, the moon moves from Capricorn into Aquarius.</p><h2>Aries (March 21-April 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> A boss, parent or someone in a position of authority might catch you off guard today or surprise you in some way. Pay attention to the rules to avoid later regrets. Meanwhile, secret love affairs will sizzle on this romantic day. Friendships will be warm and rewarding.</p><h2>Taurus (April 20-May 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> You might suddenly have to travel today. Conversely, travel plans might change, be delayed or canceled. News in the media might also hold a surprise for you. Meanwhile, friendships are warm and some platonic relationships will turn romantic on this Valentine's Day.</p><h2>Gemini (May 21-June 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Keep an eye on banking details because something unexpected could impact your assets or wealth. Meanwhile, expect to be surprised in some fashion today. It could relate to a social occasion, a vacation or a fun outing. Hopefully, it's a pleasant Valentine's surprise.</p><h2>Libra (Sept. 23-Oct. 22)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Your home routine might be interrupted today. Small appliances might break down, or a minor breakage could occur. Perhaps someone unexpected will appear at your door. Meanwhile, this is a fun-loving, playful time. A work-related romance might be your secret valentine.</p><h2>Scorpio (Oct. 23-Nov. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Pay attention to everything you say and do because this is a mildly accident-prone day for you. Don’t be distracted by something because distractions can lead to an accident. This is a romantic, social and fun-loving day. Make plans for a good time!</p><h2>Sagittarius (Nov. 22-Dec. 21)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-4d0000" name="html-embed-module-4d0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>An <b>average</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Keep an eye on your money, assets and possessions because something unexpected could impact them. For example, you might find money or you might lose money. Something you own might be lost, stolen or damaged. This is a pleasant day to entertain at home.</p><h2>Capricorn (Dec. 22-Jan. 19)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> Today the moon is in your sign, dancing with wild, unpredictable Uranus. This makes you feel energetic, original and spontaneous. Even your Spidey sense will be highly tuned. Changeable moods throughout the day are likely. Expect new friends to enter your world.</p><h2>Aquarius (Jan. 20-Feb. 18)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> This is a restless day for you. You have that feeling that you're waiting for the other shoe to drop. Nevertheless, with three planets in your sign, you are empowered, bold and forthright. Go after what you want today. It's the perfect time to buy something beautiful for a loved one (hint, hint).</p><h2>Pisces (Feb. 19-March 20)</h2> <p></p> <div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="HtmlModule"><a class="AnchorLink" id="html-embed-module-7b0000" name="html-embed-module-7b0000"></a><div class="HoroscopeStarbox HoroscopeStarbox_five"> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_container"> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> <svg class="HoroscopeStar"><use xlink:href="#icon-star"></use></svg> </div> <div class="HoroscopeStarbox_description"> <p>A <b>positive</b> day</p> </div> </div> <style> .HoroscopeStarbox { background: #f8f8f8; display: flex; align-items: center; } .HoroscopeStarbox_container { display: grid; grid-gap: 5px; grid-template-columns: 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr 1fr; padding: 20px; width: 40%; min-width: 160px; max-width: 200px; } .HoroscopeStarbox_description { padding: 20px; font-family: var(--font-1); font-size: var(--body-2); } .HoroscopeStarbox_container svg { object-fit: cover; aspect-ratio: 1 / 1; width: 100%; } </style> </div> </div><p> You are a romantic sign, and on this special Valentine's Day, fair Venus is in Pisces, stirring your romantic ideas, desires and expectations. Oh yes. If someone else doesn't give you special treatment or a little gift today, then do it yourself! Buy yourself something special. Go out and gift yourself your own fun experience. Why not?</p><h2>If today is your birthday</h2><p>Actor Enrico Colantoni (1963) shares your birthday today. You are sensitive, articulate, and clear-thinking. You want to set the world right. This year you will reap the benefits of all your hard work. Expect power and leadership. It's a year of major decisions and accomplishments. Seize opportunities. Expect awards, kudos, and acknowledgments!</p>
entries.author: Georgia Nicols

entries.title: DePaul and Loyola accused of pushing low-income families toward hefty loans while favoring wealthier students
entries.summary: <p>Two Chicago universities are among a few dozen colleges across the country that appear to favor wealthier families when offering financial aid packages, a new report finds.</p><p>Loyola University Chicago and DePaul University were named in a <a class="Link" href="https://www.newamerica.org/education-policy/reports/parent-plus-subprime-loans-universities-debt/" target="_blank" ><u>report released Thursday by the progressive think tank New America</u></a>, alleging they are among 41 colleges nationwide that push a large share of lower-income families to take out hefty loans to cover college costs while offering attractive scholarships to wealthier families with high-achieving students.</p><p>The schools in the report have a high percentage of lower-income families taking out loans they often can’t afford to pay back, according to the report’s author Steven Burd, a senior writer and editor with the education policy program at New America. The amount parents take out in loans is sometimes more than their annual earnings, the report found.</p><p>“The fear is really that they're just putting these families into real financial trouble, real financial jeopardy,” Burd said.</p><p>The report focuses on federal Parent PLUS loans, which parents can use to pay for tuition costs that can’t be covered out of pocket or through scholarships.</p><p>While most federal student loans have limits, families can take out Parent PLUS loans up to the total cost of attendance. But Parent PLUS loans, which have a high fixed interest rate and origination fees, weren’t designed for low-income families, Burd said. They were meant to help middle- and upper-income families send their children to more prestigious and expensive schools, he added.</p><p>“They were never intended as a way for schools to be able to help low-income students,” Burd said.</p><p>DePaul officials say the university provides scholarships and grants and offers information about various loans but ultimately families decide what to borrow. A Loyola University spokesperson said the university "works proactively with students and families to present all available options," without steering families toward any particular option.</p><p>"Loyola will continue strengthening resources that help families manage educational costs and minimize debt," the spokesperson said in a statement. </p><p>With Parent PLUS loans, the schools are not held accountable if the borrowers go into default, and the Trump administration is expected to soon start garnishing wages from people who have defaulted on student loans after a pause on payments that started during the COVID-19 pandemic.</p><p>Schools can offer students merit-based scholarships based on grades and academic success, even if they don’t qualify for need-based aid. And those scholarships can end up taking up a large share of a school’s financial aid funds, leaving low-income students in need of loans — and that’s where the Parent PLUS loans come in, Burd says.</p><p>The problem compounds, Burd says, when schools offer better financial aid packages to students whose families make more, a strategy he says is often aimed at attracting high-achieving and wealthy students who could give generous donations in the future. That incentivizes colleges to recruit students with an eye for “raising revenue for your institution and rising up the rankings,” Burd said.</p><p>Some schools have used this practice to improve their spot in national rankings and transform themselves from a humble commuter school to a nationally competitive university, the report says.</p><p>To find schools that appeared to be steering lower-income families toward Parent PLUS loans, Burd looked for colleges where a large share of students who received federal Pell Grants, which are meant for low-income students, had parents taking out Parent PLUS loans.</p><p>At DePaul University, 53% of students whose parents took out Parent PLUS loans were Pell Grant recipients and their parents borrowed on average $33,000 in PLUS loans, according to the report.</p><p>At Loyola, 48% of students whose parents have Parent PLUS loans had Pell grants. The average Parent PLUS debt taken on by those Loyola parents was around $46,000.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-3f0000" name="image-3f0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/32606e3/2147483647/strip/true/crop/6720x3771+0+354/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F80%2F68%2F198a9100482b85e1b0223019dd32%2Floyola-03312020-empty-university-campus-mm00001.jpg class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>At Loyola University Chicago, 48% of students whose parents have Parent PLUS loans received Pell grants for lower-income students. Their average debt load is around $46,000.</p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Manuel Martinez/WBEZ file</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>“These are families making $30,000 or less, and then they're taking on $30,000 in debt to put their kids through school,” Burd said. “These schools are charging so much, they're leaving such a large financial aid gap that the families have no other choice but to take out these PLUS loans.”</p><p>A DePaul University spokesperson said the school works to ease the financial burden on students, but didn’t directly address questions about low-income families taking out Parent PLUS loans or how the school decides what aid to offer to wealthier students. The spokesperson said DePaul provides students over $350 million a year in academic scholarships and need-based grants using institutional funds and philanthropic gifts.</p><p>“DePaul offers information to students and families regarding various loan options, and ultimately families make the decision to proceed with loans as they see fit,” the spokesperson wrote in a statement.</p><p>The 41 private and public colleges and universities cited in the report collectively spent $2.4 billion of their financial aid dollars on students who didn’t need the help in 2023, the most recent data available. Nearly $2 out of every $5 spent on financial aid went to students who the federal government considers able to afford college without additional aid, the report found.</p><p></p><p>Burd started with a list of more than 300 selective colleges and universities with a certain size endowment, excluding historically Black colleges and universities because he said they have been historically underfunded and have far less financial aid to give. Art schools were also excluded because they are among the most expensive schools, partly because of costly supplies and tools.</p><p>Burd then looked for schools at which families of Pell Grant recipients made up at least one-third of PLUS loan borrowers and the median amount of loans was at least $15,000. At the 41 schools cited in the report, 45% of the borrowers were the parents of Pell recipients, and they borrowed a median amount of $29,102.</p><p>Some lawmakers have noted this trend and have capped Parent PLUS loans at $65,000 per child, but Burd says that’s still too much for many families to borrow. He said ideally, legislation will be implemented to stop schools from steering families toward taking out loans they can’t afford to repay.</p><p>“The only other worry, though, is that private lenders are going to come in and start offering even more predatory products,” he said. “So that's something we need to look out for as well.”<br></p>
entries.author: Mary Norkol

entries.title: Mount Carmel's Liam Kelly wins in sectionals, moves a step closer to state after beating the IHSA in court
entries.summary: <p>The wrestling mat has always been Liam Kelly's happy place, but now that's even more true.</p><p>Capping a dramatic two weeks when last year's Class 3A 157-pound champ thought his bid for another state title was over, the Mount Carmel senior was back competing in the Class 3A Hinsdale Central Sectional on Friday night.</p><p>"It feels great," Kelly told the Sun-Times. "Definitely a different type of gratefulness to be out here just wrestling, one more go. I just feel blessed to be out here."</p><p>The state's top-ranked Class 3A 165-pounder according to Illinois Matmen, Kelly won three technical falls in less than six minutes of mat time to move closer to another trip downstate. He can punch his ticket Saturday for the 3A state finals, which run next Thursday through Saturday at State Farm Center in Champaign.</p><p>His path seemed blocked on Jan. 31 when officials at the Morton Regional wouldn't allow him to wrestle because of a non-contagious skin condition known as granuloma annulare, even though he had a doctor's note clearing him to compete.</p><p>"I was devastated," Kelly said. "I mean, I've had this mark my whole life. I never would have thought I'd be disqualified for it. ... I thought my season was over."</p><p>The condition has never caused an issue, either during Mount Carmel meets or outside the high-school season.</p><p>"It will get [more noticeable] during the [prep] season because I'm Irish and have fair skin," Kelly said. "... But no, it's never been a problem."</p><p>In fact, the note was accepted five days after the regional when Kelly and the Caravan wrestled in the Marmion Dual-Team Sectional.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-sports/2026/02/11/mount-carmel-ihsa-liam-kelly-wrestling" >Judge rules against IHSA, says Mount Carmel wrestler Liam Kelly can resume state title defense</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>But the IHSA initially declined to return Kelly to the individual bracket, and his father Michael filed suit in Cook County Circuit Court seeking an emergency temporary restraining order. <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/high-school-sports/2026/02/11/mount-carmel-ihsa-liam-kelly-wrestling" >Judge Alison Conlon granted the TRO on Wednesday</a> and the IHSA accepted the ruling, adding Kelly as a 13th wrestler to the 165-pound bracket at Hinsdale Central.</p><p>Like Kelly, Caravan coach Alex Tsirtsis is just glad to put the ordeal in the past.</p><p>"It was a nightmare at the regional just knowing that he's got a condition where he's been wrestling with it for the last four years and no trainers second-guessed the doctor's note or anything like that [before]," Tsirtsis told the Sun-Times. "... But we were able to get it right and it's just fun to see him compete."</p><p>Kelly credits his support system at Mount Carmel for helping him weather the storm.</p><p>"All the guys at Mount Carmel — I'm so grateful that I have a coach and a community that helps me and fights for what's right," Kelly said. "Because at any other school, there's no shot I'd be here."</p>
entries.author: Mike Clark

entries.title: As Trump administration holds back funding, new taxes could be in store for Illinois
entries.summary: <p>As I write this, Gov. JB Pritzker is preparing to give his annual budget address. It’s an unenviable task.</p><p>Earlier this month, the Governor’s Office of Management and Budget released a report showing federal tax cuts caused a $587 million reduction in state revenues this fiscal year.</p><p>The governor announced last month that he was withholding $482 million in state spending to help mitigate federal attacks on the state budget.</p><p>It’s not all horrible news. The latest monthly revenue report from the Legislature’s Commission on Government Forecasting and Accountability showed January revenues from state sources were up, according to the commission.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-b00000" name="module-b00000"></a> <div class="RichTextSidebarModule-title">Columnists bug</div> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h2>Columnists</h2><br><i>In-depth political coverage, sports analysis, entertainment reviews and cultural commentary.</i><br></div> </div><p>Personal income tax receipts increased 2.1% in January compared to the previous January (which is still below inflation). Corporate income tax revenues rose by 3.5% after months of lagging. Gross sales tax revenues increased by 3%.</p><p>Estate tax receipts are up 60%, or about $200 million, so far this fiscal year compared to last year at this time, the commission reported. The commission said asset valuation increases, including the stock market, likely contributed to the increase.</p><p>So far this fiscal year, revenues are up a bit more than $1 billion, or 3.5%, compared to the same period in fiscal year 2025.</p><p>But there is that big federal downside. According to the Commission on Government Forecasting and Accountability's report, federal revenues experienced a “notable decline,” falling $169 million, or almost 36% in January, compared to the same month last year.</p><p>During the fiscal year to date, federal sources have dropped by about 8%. But January marked the third straight month for federal revenue declines, so it may be accelerating.</p><p>“To meet initial fiscal year estimates, Federal Sources will need to show meaningful improvement over the remaining five months,” the monthly report declared. The fiscal year ends June 30.</p><h3>What else will White House cut? </h3><p>And nobody knows what tomorrow may bring. Heck, by the time you read this, something new could’ve happened. At any given moment, White House operatives could try to pull funding for whatever program they can dream up.</p><p>Last week, the Trump administration announced that it was canceling $100 million for local public health grants in Illinois.</p><p>Illinois was one of just four Democratic-led states that were targeted for the cuts.</p><p>According to the Illinois Department of Public Health, some of the cuts were for “HIV Prevention and Surveillance, which includes programs to expand HIV testing to cover more people who may not be aware they have HIV; linking newly-diagnosed patients to appropriate care; expanding access to PrEP, medication which can reduce the spread of HIV; and conducting partner notification.”</p><p>Attorney General Kwame Raoul quickly won a temporary restraining order last week, giving the state a 14-day reprieve.</p><p>Raoul has so far fought off numerous federal attempts to withhold money from the state. But there’s just no way of knowing what could happen as the litigation moves up the federal judicial food chain.</p><p>In other words, there is just no way to craft a reliable fiscal plan in this environment.</p><p>My associate Isabel Miller wrote a subscribers-only story last week for my newsletter about how more than 40 Democratic members of the Illinois House and Senate have been meeting weekly to come up with a plan to find some government efficiencies and create new revenue streams to help the state meet its obligations.</p><p>“We must lean into transforming our tax system and creating sustainable revenue to protect people and the services we all depend on,” the Affordability and Tax Justice Coalition declared in a statement.</p><p>I was told that six ideas are under discussion, and four have been introduced into bill form: A digital advertising tax — <a class="Link" href="https://ilga.gov/Legislation/BillStatus?DocNum=3353&GAID=18&DocTypeID=SB&LegId=166224&SessionID=114" target="_blank" >Senate Bill 3353</a>/<a class="Link" href="https://ilga.gov/Legislation/BillStatus?DocNum=4894&GAID=18&DocTypeID=HB&LegId=166185&SessionID=114" target="_blank" >House Bill 4894</a>); A billionaire wealth tax (<a class="Link" href="https://ilga.gov/Legislation/BillStatus?DocNum=3376&GAID=18&DocTypeID=SB&LegId=166257&SessionID=114" target="_blank" >Senate Bill 3376</a>/<a class="Link" href="https://ilga.gov/Legislation/BillStatus?DocNum=5215&GAID=18&DocTypeID=HB&LegId=166888&SessionID=114" target="_blank" >House Bill 5215</a>); Expanded tax haven reporting (<a class="Link" href="https://ilga.gov/Legislation/BillStatus?DocNum=5318&GAID=18&DocTypeID=HB&LegId=167073&SessionID=114" target="_blank" >House Bill 5318</a>/<a class="Link" href="https://ilga.gov/Legislation/BillStatus?DocNum=3486&GAID=18&DocTypeID=SB&LegId=166487&SessionID=114" target="_blank" >Senate Bill 3486</a>) and closing corporate loopholes (<a class="Link" href="https://ilga.gov/Legislation/BillStatus?DocNum=3796&GAID=18&DocTypeID=SB&LegId=167119&SessionID=114" target="_blank" >Senate Bill 3796</a>/<a class="Link" href="https://ilga.gov/Legislation/BillStatus?DocNum=5125&GAID=18&DocTypeID=HB&LegId=166713&SessionID=114" target="_blank" >House Bill 5125</a>).</p><p>As Isabel noted, House Speaker Emanuel "Chris" Welch has also been promoting a tax on millionaires, which has heartened the progressives.</p><p>Sen. Graciela Guzmán, D-Chicago, sits on the coalition’s executive committee.</p><p>“I think right now the growing sentiment is ‘Let’s get as much revenue as possible,’" Guzmán told Isabel.</p><p>Guzmán also said the coalition is pressing revenue advocates for specifics, including projected revenues for each proposal, constitutionality and implementation.</p><p>Too often, these groups just throw together proposals and hope for the best. But Guzmán said they’re focusing on whether these ideas can pass both chambers and be signed into law.</p><p>"The roll call is something that we keep talking about every week because we know the votes that we have to get up to in any one of these proposals," Guzmán told Isabel.</p><p>A lot is riding on those efforts.</p><p><i>Rich Miller also publishes Capitol Fax, a daily political newsletter, and CapitolFax.com.</i></p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-620000" name="module-620000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody">Send letters to <a class="Link" href="mailto:letters@suntimes.com" target="_blank" >letters@suntimes.com</a>. More about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/submitting-opinion-and-letters" >how to submit here</a>.</div> </div><p></p>
entries.author: Rich Miller

entries.title: A&W Contractors navigates changes in federal diversity guidelines
entries.summary: <div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-810000" name="module-810000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><b><i>Editor’s Note: </i></b><i>Last year, a new presidential administration stepped in with plans to disrupt the way companies do business through new policies, an effort to spur growth.</i><br><br><i>To help gauge the administration’s impact, the Chicago Sun-Times reached out to 10 Chicago area businesses in January 2025 and shared their plans and concerns for the future.</i><br><br><i>We’re now circling back, 12 months later, to see how they’ve fared.</i></div> </div><p>Last year marked a milestone for Air and Wellness Safety Training when it officially changed its name to A&W Contractors.</p><p>The new moniker marks the Englewood company’s bigger shift<b> </b>to construction-related work.</p><p>Former respiratory therapist <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/small-business/2025/01/24/englewood-entrepreneur-mobley-air-wellness-safety-training-economic-policy-change-looms" >Adrian Mobley</a> founded the company in 2014 to offer CPR and safety training but in 2020 moved into services such as traffic control at construction sites and then temporary fencing. Last year, A&W continued expanding into general contracting, including carpentry, flooring and joint sealant, while still offering respiratory health services.</p><p>The company is continuing work on projects at O’Hare Airport, McCormick Place, the Chicago Transit Authority’s Red Line extension to 130th Street and more.</p><p>But there is uncertainty in the infrastructure construction industry surrounding new federal diversity guidelines issued by the U.S. Department of Transportation.</p><p>In October, the Department of Transportation changed the Disadvantaged Business Enterprise program by removing race or gender as indicators of social or economic disadvantage. It previously required federally-funded construction projects to award a certain percentage of contracts to smaller firms certified as DBEs.</p><p>The department defined DBEs as for-profit small businesses in which socially and economically disadvantaged people own at least a 51% interest and control management and daily business operations. African Americans, Hispanics, Native Americans, Asian-Pacific and Subcontinent Asian Americans and women and other groups fell into that category.</p><p>A&W benefited from the CTA’s goal of awarding 20% of contracts for its $2.1 billion modernization of the Red and Purple lines to DBEs. In 2024, Mobley’s company was <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/small-business/2024/03/09/cta-dbe-program-small-business-construction-red-purple-modernization" >one of 119 minority- or female-owned businesses</a> working on the project, according to the CTA.</p><p>Now, DBEs must undergo recertification, which includes providing personal narratives along with financial documentation to prove disadvantage.</p><p>Mobley said the recertification process was more open-ended, qualitative and time-consuming. Her five-page application included answers explaining her upbringing, education, parents’ background and financial situation.</p><p>“You tell your story and hope the person who reads it thinks you’re disadvantaged,” she said. Mobley submitted her application last year expecting to be recertified. Last month, the city of Chicago notified her that A&W will be re-certified as a DBE.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-830000" name="module-830000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h4>A&W Contractors</h4><b>About:</b> Provides construction and contracting services<br><b>Neighborhood:</b> Englewood<br><b>Owners:</b> Adrian Mobley<br><b>Founded:</b> 2014<br><b>Staff size:</b> 20-30<br><b>Estimated annual revenue:</b> $5 million</div> </div><p>Recertification is “absolutely imperative” for A&W, Mobley said. At least 40% of the company’s contracts are for federally-funded projects.</p><p>A&W didn’t lose any existing contracts last year. However, some federally-funded projects were delayed, such as the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/donald-trump/2025/10/03/donald-trump-pause-funding-chicago-infrastructure-projects-red-line-extension" >CTA’s Red Line Expansion</a>. A&W is still doing demolition and temporary fencing for the Red Line project, which has started but is not in full swing, Mobley said. And the Red and Purple Modernization project wrapped up last year.</p><p>The company’s 2025 revenue was about $5 million, less than Mobley’s target of $8 million. A&W currently has 20 to 30 project-based employees, which is below last year’s goal of reaching 75 workers. But the company is much bigger than in 2020 when it had three employees.</p><p>In anticipation of an expansion, Mobley is scouting for a larger potential headquarters. She’s considering locations all over Chicago and might leave Englewood, though she would prefer to stay.</p><p>This year, she expects to hire more construction staff, such as laborers and carpenters, as well as continuing to search for administrative staff and a project manager. One challenge for A&W is integrating new technology and administrative software as it grows.</p><p>Mobley’s 2026 goals are an extension of last year’s targets, and she’s optimistic about the prospect of future projects.</p><p>“I’m excited about all the new possibilities,” she said.</p><div class="PageListA" data-module ><a class="AnchorLink" id="list-130001" name="list-130001"></a><div entries.title: Dear Abby: Friend's living situation goes from bad to worse
entries.summary: <p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> A good friend of mine, "Louis," has big problems. He is in his 60s, and although he's 50% disabled, he can still work custodial jobs. His sister, "Gayle," who lives 500 miles away, asked him to move in with her and her husband, saying they would help take care of him.</p><p>Louis moved, not realizing his sister was a severe alcoholic. She'd come home from work, have six or eight drinks and become really belligerent with both her husband and Louis. She even gave Louis 30 days to get out of her house. He has nowhere to go because he severed ties with everyone in his prior location.</p><p>I loaned Louis enough money to keep him from starving as he tried to find a means of support. He has applied for several custodial jobs. His brother-in-law is a great person but is not strong enough to do anything. Gayle has hit her husband on several occasions. They are at their wits' end and need advice. Gayle refuses to seek any kind of help. — <i>THERE FOR MY FRIEND IN FLORIDA</i></p><p><b>DEAR 'THERE':</b> Louis and his brother-in-law might find some support if they start attending Al-Anon or Smart Recovery meetings. Because they are dealing with a raging alcoholic, it may make them feel less isolated.</p><p>As to what you should advise Louis about his living situation: Since he burned his bridges in the town from which he relocated and doesn't have the funds to move out of his sister's home, all you can do is continue to listen to him and be as supportive as you can until he finds work. Because Louis is partially disabled, he may qualify for some services and assistance in his new community. Encourage him to look into these potential options further.</p><p><b>DEAR ABBY:</b> My sister-in-law and mother-in-law are going to court against each other. My mother-in-law acknowledges that she wasn't a good mother when her children were younger. My sister-in-law claims her mother was harassing her by dropping off gifts, notes and money on birthdays.</p><p>Unfortunately, my fiance and I were dragged into the middle of the situation because we were speaking with both of them prior to the court proceeding. Now, they have both cut us off! I'm pretty sure it was because we wouldn't pick sides, but why should we have to? We love them both.</p><p>My fiance had a close relationship with his sister and mother. I know this is hurting him. How can I help bring their relationships back together? My sister-in-law has blocked me from all of her accounts, and if I mail a letter, I'm afraid she will accuse me of harassing her, too. — <i>TOUGH POSITION IN PENNSYLVANIA</i></p><p><b>DEAR TOUGH POSITION:</b> There is no way you can force a reconciliation between two parties who don't want to mend fences. You do not know whether your mother-in-law's motive for dropping off unwanted gifts was to harass her daughter. (It may have been.) My advice is to stay firmly out of the line of fire until after that court case has been resolved.</p><p><b>DEAR READERS:</b> On this day that celebrates love, I want you to know how much I value my long relationship with all of you. Wishing you all a Happy Valentine's Day. — <i>WITH LOVE, ABBY</i></p><p><i>Dear Abby is written by Abigail Van Buren, also known as Jeanne Phillips, and was founded by her mother, Pauline Phillips. Contact Dear Abby at www.DearAbby.com or P.O. Box 69440, Los Angeles, CA 90069.</i></p><p>What teens need to know about sex, drugs, AIDS and getting along with peers and parents is in "What Every Teen Should Know." Send your name and mailing address, plus check or money order for $8 (U.S. funds) to: Dear Abby, Teen Booklet, P.O. Box 446, Kings Mills, OH 45034-0446. (Shipping and handling are included in the price.)</p>
entries.author: Abigail Van Buren

entries.title: As Chicago's office construction pipeline remains dry, $350 million office building opens in Fulton Market
entries.summary: <p>The only high-end office building to break ground in Chicago since 2023 has opened in Fulton Market.</p><p>The Fulton, 919 W. Fulton St., opened in late January, and the $350 million project is about 60% leased — pre-leasing hovered near 50%, according to real estate firm Transwestern.</p><p>The building bridges the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2026/02/04/harry-weese-designed-office-tower-will-get-a-25m-atrium-renovation-designed-to-lure-renters-with-amenities" >sleek amenities</a> that many companies are want for their workers and the industrial roots of Fulton Market by combining new construction with the conversion of the original Schwinn bicycle factory. </p><p>A glass atrium connects the two buildings, which has lured companies like Coca-Cola, which is leasing two floors in the former Schwinn building for its Midwest headquarters.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>Fulton Street Cos. founder and president Alex Najem is confident the building will continue to draw more tenants, as Fulton Market remains <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2024/08/23/chicago-office-rental-market-vacancy-growing-pains-west-loop-fulton-market" >one of the bright spots</a> in the city’s sluggish office market. The company also said The Fulton is the only new Class A office building to break ground, which real estate research firms have also said.</p><p>“As soon as the new year hit, it was crazy,” Najem said of interest in the building. “There’s no space left in this market.”</p><p>Research from Transwestern shows that Fulton Market is the most sought-after area for office space. The vacancy rate in Fulton Market/Near West Side is only 10.9%, the lowest of any submarket based on Transwestern's data. It’s also well below Chicago’s average office vacancy rate of 22.6%.</p><p>The vacancy rate in East Loop, by comparison, was 28.7% during the last quarter of 2025. In River North, it was 25%.</p><p>The Fulton brings much-needed office space to Fulton Market. The 11-story building spans 535,000 square feet, making it one of the neighborhood’s largest office buildings, according to Fulton Street Cos.</p><p>Fulton Street developed the building with Shanna Collective, a real estate and design firm founded by Shanna Khan. Khan’s father, Shahid, owns the Jacksonville Jaguars. Morris Adjmi Architects and FitzGerald designed the project, alongside Shanna Collective.</p><p>“Fulton Market is such a vibrant neighborhood. The energy is absolutely electric, and I am so proud that we have been embraced by this thriving community,” Khan said in a news release. “Chicago’s legacy of resilience provided a spark of inspiration in the greater calling to go all in on The Fulton. … I am betting on a bright future for Fulton Market.”</p><p>The site of the new construction was previously vacant land, Najem said, falling in the historic Fulton-Randolph Market district. </p><p>The developers negotiated with the city to build up to 180 feet tall, as long as the initial height of the new building matched the existing Schwinn building at 212 N. Peoria St., according to Najem. That resulted in a building that’s about 90 feet at the street and rises as it steps back.</p><p>The new office building features floor-to-ceiling windows, private outdoor terraces and a rooftop bar. The top floor is a hospitality-style amenity suite that includes a conference center, 4,000-square-foot fitness center, tenant lounge and outdoor terrace.</p><p>“I think a big reason why tenants are moving here is because of the amenities that we offer,” Najem said.</p><p>Tenants — like the building’s anchor, Harrison Street Asset Management — originally planned to build out more amenities within their offices, Najem said. But when they saw the offerings at The Fulton, they pulled back on some planned amenities and were able to cut costs.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item"
